Award.AwardTitle: NSF/DOE Advanced Combustion Engines: Collaborative Research: A Comprehensive Investigation of Unsteady Reciprocating Effects on Near-Wall Heat Transfer in Engines

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

1258702 / 1258594 / 1258697
White, Christopher / Jansons, Marcis / Dubief, Yves

The capacity to understand and predict heat transfer in internal combustion engines is critically important for optimizing fuel efficiency, reducing harmful engine-out emissions, and furthering advanced combustion strategies. This research project will investigate the effects of rapid transients and reciprocating effects on heat transfer in engines. The project is motivated by the fact that existing heat transfer models cannot accurately capture these effects, and in turn cannot accurately predict heat transfer over a typical drive cycle. The modeling difficulty is owed to nonlinear interactions between in-cylinder turbulence, fuel injection, combustion, piston geometry, and piston motion that produce complex thermal boundary layers along the cylinder walls. The researchers will use complimentary laboratory and numerical experiments to conduct a systematic scientific investigation focused on understanding how these nonlinear interactions affect in-cylinder heat transfer. In parallel to these fundamental studies, the researchers will develop a novel two-wavelength infrared (IR) temperature diagnostic capable of acquiring two-dimensional surface temperatures with very high temporal (kHz) and spatial resolution (μm). This dual-wavelength IR diagnostic will be used to measure piston surface temperature and local heat flux in a fired optical engine for varying engine conditions and combustion modes. The combined objective of these studies is to advance the fundamental knowledge base of thermal transport in engines and to formulate heat transfer models that account for the effects of rapid transients and reciprocating effects in engines.

This project intends to improve upon the robustness of engine heat transfer models so that they can be used for engineering design. The technological impact is the potential to optimize engine designs for reduced heat loss, improved thermal efficiency, and the removal of barriers to practical implementation of low-emission, high efficiency, low temperature combustion (LTC) engine technologies. The societal and environmental impacts of improved engine designs and implementation of LTC engine technologies are improved fuel economy, and a reduction in greenhouse emissions and atmospheric pollutants. In addition, the project will be used to attract and train highly qualified undergraduate and graduate students interested in the fields of energy, combustion, fluid dynamics, and internal combustion engines. Lastly, the proposed research will be leveraged into existing K-12 outreach programs by introducing activities focused on project specific themes, namely transport and internal combustion engines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Increasing the efficiency with which heat is converted to useful mechanical work is desirable to maintain living standards while reducing energy consumption, greenhouse gas and pollutant emissions.  Predictive capabilities to accurately describe inefficiency-inducing heat losses are requisite for the design of efficient equipment and powertrains.  However, the greatest uncertainties in engine simulations can be attributed to inadequacies in the heat transfer models they use.  To increase the ability to predict heat transfer in common machinery including internal combustion engines and compressors, this project investigated the underlying physics of how heat is transferred between gases and walls under the rapidly reciprocating conditions found in such equipment.  The project objectives were to develop an optical diagnostic for the high-frequency determination of in-cylinder temperatures and to investigate the thermal boundary layers under engine-like conditions.

Utilizing infrared sensors, a two-color diagnostic technique was developed to measure the rapidly varying surface temperatures and heat flux on the surfaces of the combustion chamber of internal combustion engines.  The fast response time of the optical method allows for the measurement of the high frequency temperature and flux fluctuations and offers advantages to traditional techniques, including being expandable to obtain two-dimensional temperature fields.  Key to the application of the novel diagnostic was the development of an algorithm to suppress the low-frequency infrared reflections and noise present in the signals inherent to the optical-access engines where such measurements are taken.  The developed diagnostic was validated against thermocouple and laser-induced phosphorescence temperature measurements under engine conditions.

To measure surface temperatures and heat flux on a combustion chamber surface during combustion, a novel technology was developed utilizing thin-film coating of optical windows.  Using a sputtering physical deposition process, 1 micron-thick layers of silicon nitride (Si3N4) and aluminum (Al) were deposited onto a sapphire window of 1.5 micron surface roughness.  The window is mounted in the combustion chamber with the coating exposed to the combustion gases.  Observed through the window, the coating temperature is measured with the infrared diagnostic, with the coating serving to block combustion luminosity that would otherwise overwhelm the surface emission.  The technology was demonstrated in a fired engine.

A micro planar laser induced (PLIF) thermometry technique utilizing a toluene tracer was applied to measure the temperature profiles in the thermal boundary layer of a motored optical engine at locations adjoining cylinder head and piston surfaces.  The 50 micron resolution of the technique allowed sufficient spatial detail to investigate the 0.5 mm-thick boundary layers.  The IR technique was applied simultaneously to provide surface temperature and flux values corresponding to the gas temperature profile measured by the PLIF thermometry.  Wall-normal and wall-parallel velocity fields were measured in the optical engine with a particle image velocimetry (PIV) technique in location and conditions corresponding to the temperature measurements.  The temperature profiles are among the first to be obtained from the thermal boundary layers of a reciprocating engine and provide experimental data against which model predictions and scaling laws can be validated.

The fidelity of state-of-the-art wall models used in commercial computational fluid dynamics (CFD) engine simulation code was evaluated by comparison of the experimentally determined temperature fields to those predicted by a numerical model of the same engine.  Experimental data was also used to evaluate log-law functions commonly used to describe temperature distributions in turbulent boundary layers.

The project has provided insight to the behavior of transient, turbulent and non-equilibrium thermal boundary layers in internal combustion engine-like environments.  The broader impact of the work is to advance the knowledge base of boundary layer transport subjected to rapid transients, the development of measurement diagnostics and validation of heat transfer models that provide the capacity to better measure and predict heat transfer in internal combustion engines, with the potential to design engines for reduced heat loss, improved thermal efficiency, and reduced emissions.
